   .
   #1 Coag Negative Staph Bacteremia:  Most recent positive cultures from
   [**12-27**]. .  Sensitivities show 2 different morphologies, sensitive to
   vanc but MIC = 2.  PICC line tip removed [**12-23**] is likely source of Coag
   neg Staph.   Throughout, patient has been afebrile. No vegetations seen
   on [**12-22**] ECHO, [**12-29**] echo.  Still no clear source for positive blood
   cultures, however were likely from PICC line, now removed.  Per
   radiology, no thrombus in veins, no arterial pseudoanerysms.
   - cont. Vancomycin, restart 14 day course based on [**12-27**] BCx
   - continue to check surveillance cultures.
   - appreciate ID recs
   #2 SOB/Resp Failure: Patient had been protecting his own airway and was
   reintubated to have MRI studies on evening of [**12-22**].  He was
   successfully extubated [**12-26**] in the afternoon, with a good follow-up
   ABG.  Lungs are clear, CXR clear.  Oxygenating well on nc.  Respiratory
   distress related more to agitation, improves w/seroquel prn doses and
   with nebulizer treatments. Not requiring many PRN nebs
   - Prednisone with 40mg today with long taper
   - Continue atrovent nebs Q6H and xopenex nebs scheduled Q4H with prn
   Q2H; no albuterol to avoid tachycardia and increased agitation
   #3 Altered Mental Status:
 Improving today with supportive care.  MRI
   of brain without evidence of significant anoxic brain injury or other
   causes to explain encephalopathy.  [**Month (only) 51**] be a result of his critical
   illness and multiple medications that he has received.  Neurology is
   following.  B12 level normal.   Per family, pt. has bipolar disorder
   and has not taken medications that he was previously prescribed.  EEG
   and EMG unrevealing.  Seroquel 150mg PO BID and PRN.  Neurology
   recommended repeat MRI but patient unable to remain still w/out being

    -trend Hct

   Assessment and Plan
   64M homeless man w h/o COPD, asthma, EtOH abuse who intially presented
   with SOB, likely COPD exacerbation, left AMA, now s/p cardiac arrest x
   2 with bilateral CTs removed for PTX.  Chest tube removed, pt
   extubated, mental status is depressed but seems to be improving.
   Persistent bacteremia with coag negative staph.
   .
   #1 Coag Negative Staph Bacteremia:  Most recent positive cultures from
   [**12-27**]. .  Sensitivities show 2 different morphologies, sensitive to
   vanc but MIC = 2.  PICC line tip removed [**12-23**] is likely source of Coag
   neg Staph.   Throughout, patient has been afebrile. No vegetations seen
   on [**12-22**] ECHO, [**12-29**] echo.  Still no clear source for positive blood
   cultures, however were likely from PICC line, now removed.  Per
   radiology, no thrombus in veins, no arterial pseudoanerysms.
   - cont. Vancomycin, restart 14 day course based on [**12-27**] BCx
   - continue to check surveillance cultures.
   - appreciate ID recs
   #2 SOB/Resp Failure: Patient had been protecting his own airway and was
   reintubated to have MRI studies on evening of [**12-22**].  He was
   successfully extubated [**12-26**] in the afternoon, with a good follow-up
   ABG.  Lungs are clear, CXR clear.  Oxygenating well on nc.  Respiratory
   distress related more to agitation, improves w/seroquel prn doses and
   with nebulizer treatments. Not requiring many PRN nebs
   - Prednisone with 40mg today with long taper
   - Continue atrovent nebs Q6H and xopenex nebs scheduled Q4H with prn
   Q2H; no albuterol to avoid tachycardia and increased agitation
   #3 Altered Mental Status:
 Improving today with supportive care.  MRI
   of brain without evidence of significant anoxic brain injury or other
   causes to explain encephalopathy.  [**Month (only) 51**] be a result of his critical
   illness and multiple medications that he has received.  Neurology is
   following.  B12 level normal.   Per family, pt. has bipolar disorder
   and has not taken medications that he was previously prescribed.  EEG
   and EMG unrevealing.  Seroquel 150mg PO BID and PRN.  Neurology
   recommended repeat MRI but patient unable to remain still w/out being
   sedated and in light of difficulty weaning patient from vent
   previously, is best to avoid re-intubation.
   - appreciate neurology recommendations.
   - f/u psych recs
   - increase Seroquel to 150mg PO TID today due to multiple PRN doses
   received last night
   # Anemia: Stable currently, but Hx stool guaiac +.
    -trend Hct
   - patient on PPI
   -transfuse if Hct <21 or patient symptomatic.
   #Hypertension: On reviewing old records, pt. has a history of HTN and
   was previously discharged from this institution on lisinopril and
   atenolol.  Thus, he likely has HTN at baseline and requires some
   medication for this.  HTN also corresponds to agitation.   Continue
   Captopril at 37.5 PO TID as his HTN is improved today.
   - regimen is Amlodipine 5mg PO qday, Captopril 37.5mg PO TID
   - Holding beta blocker as pt. is bradycardic at times, bronchospastic
   - No albuterol
   - Control agitation with seroquel
   #Hypernatremia:
   - continue free water boluses
   - follow Na w/am labs and adjust water flushes as appropriate.
   # CAD s/p silent myocardial infarction: s/p cardiac arrest and multiple
   shocks.
   - Add ASA
   - Hold B-blocker given intermittent bradycardia, bronchospasm
   - Consider statin.
   # Medical decision making:
   - Family (brother & son) visited patient this weekend and were
   encouraged by his progress.  They will try to have family visiting to
   help orient patient and provide a familiar face.
   - Pursing guardianship
 paperwork done by medical team, SW working
   with family
   - okay with PEG placement if deemed medically necessary.
   .
   # PTSD/bipolar disorder: Appears that he is not on medications as
   outpatient. Per family, has been seen in VA system.
   - psych f/u
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: Patient with BG 133-170 currently.
   -on low level standing glargine and regular insulin with sliding scale
   .
   # FEN:  Pt. tolerating TFs per nutrition recs.  Replete electrolytes
   PRN.  Failed speech and swallow eval but hope MS will improve over
   time.
   .
   # Access:  PIV, requesting PICC line
   # PPx:  Heparin SC TID, bowel regimen, On PPI
   # Code:  FULL code, confirmed with brother & son, will revisit if
   status deteriorates.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old homeless man with a history of COPD, asthma, and EtOH abuse who presented with SOB and likely COPD exacerbation. He was intubated, had a cardiac arrest, and underwent bilateral CT removal for pneumothorax. He was extubated and has been in the ICU for several days.

The patient has been diagnosed with coag-negative staph bacteremia, which was likely related to the PICC line, which was removed. He has been treated with vancomycin and is being monitored for surveillance cultures.

The patient has also been experiencing respiratory distress, which is being managed with oxygen therapy, nebulizer treatments, and steroids. His mental status has been depressed, but is improving with supportive care.

The patient has a history of hypertension and was previously discharged on lisinopril and atenolol. He has also been diagnosed with anemia, hypernatremia, and CAD with a silent myocardial infarction.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.2-7.2 K/uL
* Hct: 27.4-28.6%
* Plt: 295-390 K/uL
* Cr: 0.8-0.7 mg/dL
* TCO2: 34-39 mmHg
* Glucose: 107-135 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.6 g/dL
* LDH: 454 IU/L
* Ca++: 9.1 mg/dL
* Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Vancomycin
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Prednisone
* Seroquel
* Captopril
* Amlodipine
* ASA
* Statin
* Glargine and regular insulin with sliding scale for hyperglycemia
* PPI

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing vancomycin and monitoring for surveillance cultures
* Managing respiratory distress with oxygen therapy, nebulizer treatments, and steroids
* Monitoring mental status and adjusting medications as needed
* Treating hypertension with captopril and amlodipine
* Monitoring and managing anemia, hypernatremia, and CAD
* Providing supportive care and monitoring for hyperglycemia
* Considering PEG placement if deemed medically necessary
* Pursuing guardianship and medical decision-making with the patient's family
* Managing PTSD and bipolar disorder with psychotropic medications and therapy

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock from the coag-negative staph bacteremia
* Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Cardiac arrest and arrhythmias from the CAD and hypertension
* Renal failure from the hypernatremia and hypertension
* Gastrointestinal bleeding from the anemia and hypertension
* Infection and sepsis from the PICC line and other invasive devices
* Neurological complications from the encephalopathy and stroke

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his multiple medical conditions to prevent complications and promote recovery.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-inch tall individual, weighing 68.6 kg, with a current temperature of 36.2C, heart rate of 107 bpm, and blood pressure of 150/85 mmHg. The patient has a sinus tachycardia rhythm and is receiving prophylactic heparin. The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a respiratory rate of 31 inspirations per minute and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air.

The patient has a PICC line inserted and is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin. The patient's labs show a white blood cell count of 8.2, hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 390 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic respiratory failure, hypertension, and anxiety. The patient has a current diagnosis of acute respiratory failure, anemia, and altered mental status.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. This may indicate respiratory failure, which can progress to respiratory arrest.
2. Infection: The patient is receiving antibiotics, which may indicate a suspected or confirmed infection. Infections can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
3. Bleeding: The patient has a platelet count of 390 K/uL, which may indicate a risk of bleeding. Bleeding can lead to hypovolemic shock, organ failure, and death.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, which may indicate an electrolyte imbalance. Electrolyte imbalances can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 9.9 g/dL, which may indicate anemia. Anemia can lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may be a sign of sepsis, electrolyte imbalance, or other underlying conditions. Altered mental status can lead to decreased cognitive function, confusion, and increased risk of falls.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's sinus tachycardia rhythm and elevated blood pressure may indicate cardiovascular instability. Cardiovascular instability can lead to cardiac arrest, myocardial infarction, and other complications.

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely to prevent or identify these potential complications early.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old homeless man with a history of COPD, asthma, and EtOH abuse who presented with SOB, likely COPD exacerbation, and later developed cardiac arrest with bilateral CT removal for pneumothorax. He was extubated and has been receiving treatment for coag-negative staph bacteremia, which was likely related to the PICC line. The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, altered mental status, anemia, hypertension, hypernatremia, and hyperglycemia. He has a history of CAD, PTSD, and bipolar disorder.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure, especially if not managed properly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia may lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may not be adequately controlled, leading to cardiovascular complications.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to central pontine myelinolysis, a potentially life-threatening condition.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may lead to diabetic ketoacidosis, a life-threatening condition.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory distress may be related to pneumonia, which can worsen his condition.
8. Cardiac Complications: The patient's CAD and history of cardiac arrest may lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status may be related to his critical illness, medications, or underlying neurological conditions, and may worsen if not managed properly.
10. Infection: The patient's bacteremia may lead to other infections, such as urinary tract infections or skin infections, which can worsen his condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory distress with oxygen therapy, nebulizers, and bronchodilators.
2. Monitor the patient's blood cultures and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and iron supplementation.
4. Monitor the patient's hypertension and adjust antihypertensive therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia with free water boluses and adjust electrolyte therapy as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's hyperglycemia and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
7. Consider adding statin therapy to manage the patient's CAD.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust medications as necessary.
9. Consider repeating MRI to rule out other causes of altered mental status.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a complicated medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a history of cardiac arrests. He was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of shortness of breath, agitation, and respiratory distress. He developed a seizure and PEA arrest, which was successfully resuscitated. He was intubated and transferred to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9C (98.4F)
* Heart rate: 110 bpm (normal range: 95-132 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 122/67 mmHg (normal range: 75-160/94 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 32 inspirations per minute (normal range: 15-38 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 100% (normal range: 95-100%)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 437 K/uL (normal range: 4.5-11.0 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 10.4 g/dL (normal range: 13.5-17.5 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 437 K/uL (normal range: 150-450 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/dL)
* Blood urea nitrogen: 23 mg/dL (normal range: 7-20 mg/dL)
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL (normal range: 70-100 mg/dL)

The patient's medications include:

* Captopril changed to Lisinopril 10mg PO qday
* Heparin Sodium (prophylaxis)
* Vancomycin
* Seroquel 150mg PO TID for agitation
* Prednisone 30mg PO qday (starting tomorrow morning)
* Xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers for respiratory distress
* Aspirin
* Amiodarone (discontinued)
* Beta blocker (held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory distress)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* COPD exacerbation
* Altered mental status/bipolar disorder
* Coag-negative staph bacteremia
* Hypertension
* Abnormal neuro exam
* s/p cardiac arrest
* ETOH abuse
* History of alcoholic hepatitis
* FEN (failure to thrive)
* Medical decision making (inability to communicate own wishes)

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation
* Sepsis and septic shock due to coag-negative staph bacteremia
* Neurological deterioration due to prolonged ICU stay, bacteremia, and intubation
* Cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest due to hypertension and cardiac disease
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer and coagulopathy
* Infection and sepsis due to poor wound care and inadequate antibiotic treatment
* Pneumonia and respiratory failure due to prolonged intubation and respiratory distress
* Malnutrition and poor wound healing due to inadequate nutrition and hydration
* Psychiatric complications such as delirium, agitation, and depression due to prolonged ICU stay and medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a complicated medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a recent episode of PEA arrest. He was previously treated for a seizure in the lobby, and his hospital course has been complicated by PTX, AMS/agitation, and coag-negative staph bacteremia. The patient has been improving since an IV steroid course, but his respiratory status has become unstable, and he has been transferred back to the ICU for agitation and concern for respiratory distress.

The patient has been diagnosed with coag-negative staph bacteremia, which has been treated with vancomycin, and his source of infection is unclear. He has had extensive workup, including TTE, LENIs, and MRI of head and C-spine, but no clear source of infection has been identified.

The patient has also been experiencing altered mental status, which is likely due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis, superimposed delirium, and prolonged ICU stay. He has been treated with seroquel and prednisone, and his mental status has begun to improve.

The patient has a history of ETOH abuse, and his arrest may have been due to withdrawal seizure given the timing of his serum EtOH levels. He has been off benzodiazepines for over a week and has been started on folate, thiamine, and MVI.

The patient has failed a speech and swallow evaluation and is currently receiving tube feeds via NGT. He may require a PEG, and his family is being educated on the need for repeat speech and swallow evaluation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Persistent bacteremia: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia may not be fully treated, and he may continue to experience bacteremia, which could lead to further complications.
2. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may continue to experience respiratory distress, which could lead to further complications, such as acute respiratory failure.
3. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may continue to worsen, leading to further complications, such as delirium, agitation, and potentially even seizures.
4. Polyneuropathy: The patient's EMG showed concerning findings for polyneuropathy, which could lead to further complications, such as weakness, numbness, and paralysis.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of PEA arrest and cardiac arrest cooling protocol may increase his risk of further cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of ETOH abuse and abdominal pain may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as pancreatitis and gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Nutritional complications: The patient's inability to tolerate food and his need for tube feeds may lead to nutritional complications, such as malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition make him at high risk for further complications. Close monitoring and management of his condition are essential to prevent and manage these complications.

   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   - would favor treating through [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access
   - appreciate ID input
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.
   - on Lisinopril 10mg PO qday, Amlodipine 5mg PO qday
   - use seroquel for hypertension associated with episodes of agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress
   - continue telemetry
    .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for over one week.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   ..
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN He failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**], continue with
   tube feeds via NGT for now, may require PEG.  Appears that he is likely
   at a new baseline and concern for little improvement from here.  Will
   continue to assess and address with family.
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call
   [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 3793**] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 7-1888 on friday. attorney @[**Hospital1 **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a complicated medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a recent seizure in the lobby, followed by a PEA arrest. The patient has been treated for coag-negative staph bacteremia, and a new blood culture is positive. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is stable on nebulizers and seroquel, with an ABG of 7.3/56/57/38.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with lisinopril and amlodipine, and has a history of cardiac arrest.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis and superimposed delirium, and has an abnormal neuro exam, including polyneuropathy.
* Infectious disease: The patient has coag-negative staph bacteremia, with unclear source, and is being treated with vancomycin.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a nasogastric tube for feeding and has failed a speech and swallow evaluation.
* Endocrine: The patient has abnormal LFTs and is being treated for ethanol abuse.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory distress
* Cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, due to hypertension and cardiac history
* Neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy, due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis and superimposed delirium
* Infectious complications, such as sepsis or organ failure, due to coag-negative staph bacteremia
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration or malnutrition, due to nasogastric tube feeding
* Endocrine complications, such as adrenal insufficiency or hypoglycemia, due to ethanol abuse and underlying medical conditions.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course
* Continue seroquel for agitation and hypertension
* Continue nebulizers and ipratropium for respiratory distress
* Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation
* Monitor mental status and neuro exam
* Continue aspirin and telemetry for cardiac arrest
* Continue folate, thiamine, and MVI for ethanol abuse
* Continue tube feeds via NGT and assess for PEG placement
* Pursue guardianship due to patient's inability to communicate his own wishes.

Summary:

The patient, a 64-year-old man, has been in the ICU for respiratory failure, PEA arrest, and bilateral pneumothoraces. He was readmitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress. He has a prolonged hospital stay, with a history of coag-negative staph bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin. He is also on prophylactic heparin and has a PICC line. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8C, heart rate of 110 bpm, and blood pressure of 140/89 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 97%. His lab results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. He is on a steroid taper for COPD and is being treated with Advair and nebulizers.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia could lead to sepsis, which could worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of organ dysfunction.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and COPD could lead to respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation.
3. Bleeding Complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy could increase the risk of bleeding complications, such as hematuria or hemoptysis.
4. Infection: The patient's bacteremia could lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
5. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of PEA arrest and prolonged hospital stay could increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's prolonged hospital stay and sedation could increase the risk of neurological complications, such as delirium or cognitive impairment.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's prolonged hospital stay and medications could increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or constipation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old man with a prolonged hospital stay for respiratory failure, PEA arrest, and bilateral pneumothoraces. He has been readmitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8C (98.2F), heart rate of 110 bpm, blood pressure of 140/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. His physical examination is notable for bibasilar crackles on lung examination, diminished peripheral pulses, and soft and non-tender abdomen.

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 396 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 8.2 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 20 mg/dL
* Sodium: 139 mEq/L

* Albumin: 3.6 g/dL
* LDH: 454 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient has been diagnosed with COPD, coag-negative staph bacteremia, and is being treated with vancomycin through his central line. He has a history of ETOH abuse and is being managed with ICU care, including nutrition support and glycemic control.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and bilateral pneumothoraces put him at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia can lead to sepsis, which can worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's history of PEA arrest and tachycardia put him at risk for cardiovascular instability.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of ETOH abuse and stress ulcer prophylaxis may increase his risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's central line and other invasive devices increase his risk for infection.
6. Renal failure: The patient's history of bilateral pneumothoraces and respiratory failure may increase his risk for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent these potential complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-inch tall, 68.6 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of respiratory failure, acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and anemia secondary to blood loss. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 94 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/56 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.2 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 295. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL. The patient's liver function is also impaired, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 25 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 20 IU/L.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to his impaired motor function, but his skin is described as normal. His neurological examination is also limited, but he is able to respond to verbal commands.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and anxiety. He has a history of respiratory failure, chronic.

The patient's ICU care plan includes nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer. The patient is also at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and is being monitored closely for signs of infection.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and acute exacerbation of COPD increase his risk of respiratory failure.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia secondary to blood loss increases his risk of cardiac arrest and other complications.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and his current condition increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Infection: The patient's impaired immune function and his presence in the ICU increase his risk of infection.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's impaired renal function and his presence in the ICU increase his risk of fluid overload.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's impaired renal function and his presence in the ICU increase his risk of electrolyte imbalance.
7. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and his presence in the ICU increase his risk of delirium.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient's impaired mobility and his presence in the ICU increase his risk of pressure ulcers.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. His condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a recent cardiac arrest. He was admitted to the MICU with a seizure, PEA arrest, and subsequent hospital course complicated by PTX, AMS, and coag-negative staph bacteremia.

The patient's current condition is stable, with stable respiratory status on prednisone taper, but he continues to experience daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis. These episodes are managed with nebs and seroquel. He has also had episodes of somnolence, which are being treated with a lower dose of seroquel.

The patient's altered mental status is likely due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar disorder, and superimposed delirium. He has had a MRI brain without evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain encephalopathy.

The patient has a new culture positive for coag-negative staph bacteremia, with an unclear source. He has had extensive workup in the past, including TTE, LENIs, and MRI of head and C-spine, but would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE without re-intubation.

The patient's hypertension is being managed with lisinopril and amlodipine, and he becomes hypertensive during episodes of agitation, which are resolved with seroquel.

The patient's abnormal neuro exam is improving with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation. He had an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy, but B12 was normal.

The patient's past medical history includes cardiac arrest, EtOH abuse, and history of alcoholic hepatitis.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, seroquel, xopenex, ipratropium nebulizers, prednisone, lisinopril, amlodipine, and aspirin.

The patient's potential medical complications that can arise from his current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD exacerbation and respiratory distress increase his risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia increases his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and abnormal neuro exam increase his risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and hypertension increase his risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of EtOH abuse and history of alcoholic hepatitis increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as pancreatitis or gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia increases his risk of developing infection.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's inability to take adequate POs increases his risk of malnutrition.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his medications as needed to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Continue to treat the patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia with vancomycin and monitor his blood cultures for resolution.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medications as needed to prevent neurological complications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust his medications as needed to prevent cardiovascular complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his medications as needed to prevent gastrointestinal complications.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his diet as needed to prevent malnutrition.
7. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist to evaluate the patient's history of EtOH abuse and history of alcoholic hepatitis.
8. Consider consulting with a neurologist to evaluate the patient's altered mental status and abnormal neuro exam.
9. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to evaluate the patient's history of cardiac arrest and hypertension.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, bipolar disorder, and a history of cardiac arrests. He was admitted to the ICU with a seizure, PEA arrest, and subsequent hospital course complicated by PTX, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress, and coag-negative staph bacteremia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: stable with ABG of 7.3/56/57/38, but still requiring nebulizers and seroquel for agitation
* Neurological status: improving with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation, but still has abnormal reflexes and encephalopathy
* Cardiovascular status: hypertension is well-controlled on current regimen, but becomes hypertensive with agitated episodes
* Gastrointestinal status: tube feeds via NGT due to failed speech and swallow evaluation
* Infection status: coag-negative staph bacteremia, with unclear source, and being treated with vancomycin

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory distress
* Cardiac arrest: due to underlying cardiac conditions and hypertension
* Infection: due to coag-negative staph bacteremia and potential sources such as the femoral arteries or head and C-spine
* Neurological deterioration: due to underlying encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes
* Gastrointestinal complications: due to tube feeds via NGT and potential need for PEG
* Hypertension: due to underlying conditions and medication regimen
* Altered mental status: due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis, superimposed delirium, and medication side effects

The patient's medical decision-making is complicated by his inability to communicate his own wishes, and his son is pursuing guardianship. The patient's disposition is appropriate for rehabilitation, pending guardianship finalization.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old man with a complicated hospital course, including respiratory failure, PEA arrest, and a recent episode of respiratory distress resolved with seroquel. He is currently in the ICU and is being treated for respiratory failure due to COPD and VAP. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.7C, heart rate of 109 bpm, and blood pressure of 144/77 mmHg. He is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and respiratory support. His lab results show evidence of sepsis, with elevated white blood cell count, lactate acid, and creatinine levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's lab results suggest sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to COPD and VAP, which can worsen if not treated with adequate respiratory support and antibiotics.
3. Delirium: The patient's delirium is likely due to anoxic brain injury and may worsen if not treated with sedation and neuromuscular blockade.
4. Infection: The patient's Coag-negative staph infection may spread to other parts of his body, leading to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
5. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid balance data shows a total fluid intake of 3,352 mL and a total fluid output of 2,185 mL, which may indicate fluid overload and put him at risk for heart failure and respiratory distress.
6. Bleeding Risk: The patient's anticoagulant therapy may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of sepsis and respiratory failure.
7. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants and antibiotics may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly in the setting of sepsis and respiratory failure.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for serious complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, delirium, and infection. Close monitoring and aggressive treatment are necessary to prevent these complications and improve his outcome.

The patient is a 64-year-old man with a complex medical history, admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, PEA arrest, and a complicated hospital course. He has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, and has undergone fluoroscopy and other diagnostic procedures. His vital signs are stable, but he remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. He has a history of COPD and VAP, and his delirium is still present. He is also at risk for DVT and stress ulcers.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and he requires ongoing mechanical ventilation. He is at risk for further respiratory deterioration, and his condition may not improve without further intervention.
2. VAP: The patient has a history of VAP, and he is still intubated, which increases his risk for further VAP episodes. He requires ongoing surveillance and treatment for VAP.
3. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his prolonged immobility and medical condition. He requires prophylactic anticoagulation therapy to prevent DVT.
4. Stress ulcers: The patient is at risk for stress ulcers due to his critical illness and medical treatment. He requires prophylactic treatment with a proton pump inhibitor to prevent stress ulcers.
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium is a significant concern, and he requires ongoing treatment and management to prevent further deterioration. His delirium may be due to his anoxic brain injury, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to address this issue.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of infection, and he is at risk for further infection due to his compromised immune system and prolonged hospital stay. He requires ongoing surveillance and treatment for infection.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's PEA arrest and history of cardiac disease make him at risk for cardiovascular instability. He requires ongoing monitoring and treatment to prevent further cardiovascular events.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old man with a complex hospital course, including respiratory failure, PEA arrest, and complications. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.2C (98.9F)
* Heart rate: 109 bpm (87-122 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 144/77 mmHg (92-201/125 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute (15-37 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 95%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 381 K/uL
* Platelet count: 295
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Glucose: 142 mg/dL
* Other lab results are also provided.

The patient's physical examination is significant for:

* Wheezes in both lungs
* Absent radial and dorsalis pedis pulses in both legs
* Soft, non-tender abdomen with present bowel sounds
* Confused mental status
* Warm skin

The patient's medical history is significant for COPD, and he has been diagnosed with VAP. The patient is receiving treatment for respiratory failure, including fiberoptic bronchoscopy and mechanical ventilation. The patient is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Cardiovascular instability
* Delirium
* Neurological deficits
* Skin breakdown
* Pressure ulcers

Based on the patient's complex hospital course and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and optimize outcomes.

   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   # Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Last night he had one such
   episode that resolved with 2 PRN doses of 50mg of Seoquel and 1 dose of
   1mg of Ativan.  This morning he was not moving air well but that is
   likely due to the fact that he was due to have a nebulizer treatment.
   Previous episodes have demonstratred normal ABGs.
   -Considering Seroquel dose was lowered two days ago and prns were
   needed, will increase am and qhs seroquel doses t o150mg and f/u
   w/psych recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 30mg PO qday then 20 mg
   qday starting [**1-8**]
   .
   # Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased am and qhs doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive with
   unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    Vanco dose has been increased, will recheck level.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -appreciate ID input
   -will replace picc with one in other arm
   -if additional BCx come back positive, would favor treating through
   [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access\
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Lisinopril 10mg PO qday, Amlodipine 5mg PO qday
   - BP has been relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril, can decrease to 5mg
   Lisinopril PO.
   - use Seroquel for hypertension associated with episodes of agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   ..
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate POs
   and it is clear that the patient is not aspirating.  CXR today was
   normal
   -f/u CXR tomorrow.
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call
   [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 3793**] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 7-1888 on friday. attorney @[**Hospital1 **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a complicated medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a recent PEA arrest. He was transferred back to the ICU from the floor due to continued episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He has a history of respiratory distress and is currently on oxygen therapy. He has been experiencing daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which are likely related to his COPD and EtOH abuse.
* Neurological: He has altered mental status, likely due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis, superimposed delirium, and prolonged ICU stay. He is currently on seroquel for agitation and has been showing some improvement in his mental status.
* Cardiovascular: He has a history of hypertension and was previously on lisinopril and atenolol. His blood pressure has improved on his current regimen, but he becomes hypertensive during episodes of agitation, which resolves with seroquel.
* Infection: He has a coag-negative staph bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin. He has had extensive workup, including TTE, LENIs, and MRI of the head and C-spine, but the source of the infection remains unclear.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a history of abnormal liver function tests, but his current LFTs are normal. He has a Dubhoff tube in place and is being started on ground solids and thin liquids due to his failed speech and swallow evaluation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and history of COPD increase his risk of respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia increases his risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and prolonged ICU stay increase his risk of delirium, which can lead to increased agitation, hallucinations, and other complications.
* Neurological damage: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and prolonged ICU stay increase his risk of neurological damage, including seizures, stroke, and encephalopathy.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of abnormal liver function tests and prolonged ICU stay increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.

In terms of treatment, the patient is being managed with oxygen therapy, seroquel for agitation, and vancomycin for his coag-negative staph bacteremia. He is also being started on ground solids and thin liquids due to his failed speech and swallow evaluation. Further management will depend on the patient's response to treatment and the results of his ongoing workup.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a history of seizures. He was admitted to the ICU with severe respiratory distress, agitation, and bacteremia. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient continues to experience daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which are managed with nebs and seroquel. His respiratory status is stable, and he is able to move more air in his lungs than usual.
* Neurological: The patient's mental status has improved with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation. He is able to converse and follow simple commands. However, his neuro exam remains abnormal, and he has a concerning EMG result suggesting polyneuropathy.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on current medications, although he becomes hypertensive during episodes of agitation. He is on lisinopril and amlodipine, and his beta blocker has been held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory distress.
* Infectious: The patient has a coag-negative staph bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin. The source of the infection is unclear, and the patient has had extensive workup in the past without finding a clear explanation.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of alcoholic hepatitis and is currently on folate, thiamine, and MVI supplements. He is being fed through a TF and is starting with ground solids and thin liquids due to his lack of teeth and risk of aspiration.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory distress and wheezing could lead to respiratory failure if not managed appropriately.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia could progress to sepsis if not adequately treated.
3. Neurological deterioration: The patient's abnormal neuro exam and polyneuropathy could worsen if not managed with appropriate treatment.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypertension and tachycardia could lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of alcoholic hepatitis and current TF could lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
6. Infection control: The patient's bacteremia and ongoing antibiotic treatment require careful monitoring to prevent antibiotic resistance and ensure effective treatment.
7. Rehabilitation: The patient's ability to communicate his own wishes is uncertain, and his son is pursuing guardianship. The patient's medical decision-making capacity should be assessed and documented to ensure appropriate care.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory, neurological, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old man with severe COPD, admitted with an exacerbation complicated by PEA arrest and prolonged hospitalization. The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, requiring multiple doses of seroquel to reduce agitation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.2C (97.2F)
* Heart rate: 101 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 86/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 93%
* SpO2: 93%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: No acute distress
* Eyes and conjunctiva: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Head, ears, nose, and throat: Normocephalic (normal head shape)
* Lymphatic: Cervical WNL (normal)
* Cardiovascular: S1 and S2 heart sounds are normal, but the patient has diminished peripheral pulses
* Respiratory/chest: Clear breath sounds with diminished breath sounds bilaterally
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, and bowel sounds are present
* Extremities: Right and left radial pulses are absent, with diminished distal pulses
* Musculoskeletal: Muscle wasting, unable to stand
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Sedated, responsive only to pain, with no motor or sensory function

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.2 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 9.6 K/uL
* Platelet count: 298 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 110 mg/dL
* Other lab results are within normal limits

The patient has a diagnosis of coag-negative staph bacteremia, with cultures negative since January 2nd.

The plan for the patient includes:

* Agitation: Continue to sedate with seroquel and try to increase dose at night
* COPD: Continue to wean steroids every 3 days
* Coag-negative staph bacteremia: Monitor for signs of infection and adjust treatment as needed
* HTN: Hold lisinopril due to low blood pressure and consider alternative antihypertensive medications
* Nutrition: Provide a PO diet and calorie count when awake
* ICU care: Continue to monitor vital signs, administer medications, and provide respiratory support as needed

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation
* Sepsis or septic shock due to coag-negative staph bacteremia
* Cardiac complications due to PEA arrest and prolonged hospitalization
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer disease
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and prolonged hospitalization
* Infection due to prolonged hospitalization and use of invasive devices.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   #1 Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Last night he had one such
   episode that resolved with 2 PRN doses of 50mg of Seoquel and 1 dose of
   1mg of Ativan.  This morning and last he was not moving air well but
   that is likely due to the fact that he was due to have a nebulizer
   treatment.  Previous episodes have demonstratred normal ABGs.
   -Considering Seroquel dose was lowered three days ago and although
   increased yesterday prns were needed, will increase doses to
   200/150/200 w/25mg PRNs (with total of 800mg daily MAX) and f/u w/psych
   recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 30mg PO qday then 20 mg
   qday starting [**1-8**]
   .
   #2 Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #3 Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive
   with unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    Vanco dose has been increased, will recheck level.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -appreciate ID input
   -will replace picc with one in other arm tomorrow (in IR) if BCx from
   [**1-4**] still pending or turns positive
   -if additional BCx come back positive after PICC replaced, team would
   favor treating through [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril,
   decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was transferred back to the ICU due to respiratory distress and agitation. He has a complex medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a history of cardiac arrest.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient has daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which are treated with nebs and seroquel. His ABGs are normal.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has hypertension, which is managed with amlodipine and lisinopril. He also has a history of cardiac arrest, for which he was treated with an amiodarone drip, which was subsequently discontinued.
* Neurological status: The patient has altered mental status, which is likely due to underlying psychiatric diagnoses, such as bipolar disorder or schizoaffective disorder, as well as superimposed delirium. He also has abnormal reflexes and encephalopathy, which are being treated with seroquel.
* Infectious disease: The patient has coag-negative staph bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin. He also has a history of respiratory failure and sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a history of alcoholic hepatitis and is currently being treated with folate, thiamine, and MVI.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and is being fed through a feeding tube.
* Wound care: The patient has a wound on his chest, which is being treated with antibiotics and wound care.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require mechanical ventilation to manage his respiratory distress.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis and bacteremia, which can lead to multi-organ failure if not properly managed.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status and encephalopathy can worsen if not properly managed, leading to further neurological deterioration.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and hypertension can lead to cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of alcoholic hepatitis and current gastrointestinal symptoms can lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.

In terms of the patient's current management, the physician is increasing the dose of seroquel to manage the patient's agitation and anxiety. The patient is also being treated with vancomycin for his bacteremia, and his antibiotics are being adjusted based on his blood cultures. The patient is also receiving total parenteral nutrition and is being fed through a feeding tube.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   # Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Last night he had one such
   episode that resolved with 2 PRN doses of 50mg of Seoquel and 1 dose of
   1mg of Ativan.  This morning he was not moving air well but that is
   likely due to the fact that he was due to have a nebulizer treatment.
   Previous episodes have demonstratred normal ABGs.
   -Considering Seroquel dose was lowered two days ago and prns were
   needed, will increase am and qhs seroquel doses t o150mg and f/u
   w/psych recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 30mg PO qday then 20 mg
   qday starting [**1-8**]
   .
   # Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased am and qhs doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive with
   unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    Vanco dose has been increased, will recheck level.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -appreciate ID input
   -will replace picc with one in other arm
   -if additional BCx come back positive, would favor treating through
   [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access\
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Lisinopril 10mg PO qday, Amlodipine 5mg PO qday
   - BP has been relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril, can decrease to 5mg
   Lisinopril PO.
   - use Seroquel for hypertension associated with episodes of agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   ..
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate POs
   and it is clear that the patient is not aspirating.  CXR today was
   normal
   -f/u CXR tomorrow.
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call
   [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 3793**] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 7-1888 on friday. attorney @[**Hospital1 **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]  .
   .
   #PPX: heparin sc, PPI, bowel regimen.
   .
   #Dispo: Appropriate for rehab. Screening in progress.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a history of cardiac arrest. He was admitted with symptoms of shortness of breath and later developed bacteremia, respiratory distress, and altered mental status.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: He is experiencing daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which are likely related to his underlying COPD. He is being treated with nebulizers and seroquel.
* Mental status: He is still experiencing altered mental status, which is likely related to his underlying psychiatric diagnosis and superimposed delirium. He is being treated with seroquel.
* Bacteremia: He has a coag-negative staph bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin.
* Neurological status: He has abnormal reflexes and an abnormal neuro exam, which is being monitored.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Given the patient's underlying COPD and respiratory distress, there is a risk of respiratory failure, which could lead to the need for mechanical ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia could lead to sepsis, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
* Delirium: The patient's altered mental status could worsen, leading to further delirium and agitation.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's abnormal reflexes and neuro exam could worsen, leading to further neurological deterioration.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is likely to remain elevated, given his underlying hypertension and agitation.
* Cardiac issues: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and cardiac issues could lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing seroquel for agitation and respiratory distress
* Increasing the dose of seroquel to 150mg and 25mg PRN
* Continuing nebulizers and ipratropium
* Continuing slow prednisone taper
* Monitoring mental status and neuro exam
* Continuing vancomycin for bacteremia
* Replacing PICC line with a line in the other arm
* Monitoring for further episodes of respiratory distress and bacteremia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with severe COPD, who had a prolonged hospital stay after a PEA arrest. He is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5C, heart rate of 99 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 156/49 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 27 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.

The patient's physical examination is significant for wheezing breath sounds bilaterally, and his lung fields are clear. He has a soft, non-tender abdomen, and his extremities are warm. His neurological examination is limited due to his agitation and inability to follow commands.

The patient's laboratory results are significant for a white blood cell count of 8.3 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 10.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 344 x 10^9/L. His blood urea nitrogen is 19 mg/dL, and his creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL. His liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate transaminase of 25 IU/L and an alanine transaminase of 20 IU/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for COPD, and he is currently receiving treatment with prednisone, atrovent, and zopenex. He is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics for a suspected coagulase-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing his COPD treatment, monitoring his respiratory status, and managing his agitation with seroquel. He will also undergo further evaluation and treatment for his suspected bacteremia.

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
