   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   #1 Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Last night he had one such
   episode that resolved with 2 PRN doses of 50mg of Seoquel and 1 dose of
   1mg of Ativan.  This morning and last he was not moving air well but
   that is likely due to the fact that he was due to have a nebulizer
   treatment.  Previous episodes have demonstratred normal ABGs.
   -Considering Seroquel dose was lowered three days ago and although
   increased yesterday prns were needed, will increase doses to
   200/150/200 w/25mg PRNs (with total of 800mg daily MAX) and f/u w/psych
   recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 30mg PO qday then 20 mg
   qday starting [**1-8**]
   .
   #2 Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #3 Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive
   with unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    Vanco dose has been increased, will recheck level.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -appreciate ID input
   -will replace picc with one in other arm tomorrow (in IR) if BCx from
   [**1-4**] still pending or turns positive
   -if additional BCx come back positive after PICC replaced, team would
   favor treating through [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril,
   decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   .
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate POs
   and it is clear that the patient is not aspirating.  CXR today was
   normal
   -f/u CXR tomorrow.
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call
   [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 3793**] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 7-1888 on friday. attorney @[**Hospital1 **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]

   .

   .

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the MICU with a complicated medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a recent PEA arrest. He has been experiencing daily episodes of respiratory distress, which have been managed with nebulizers and seroquel. He has also been experiencing altered mental status, which is likely due to underlying psychiatric conditions, delirium, and bacteremia.

The patient has a coag-negative staph bacteremia, which has been treated with vancomycin. He has also been experiencing hypertension, which has been managed with medication. His neuro exam has been abnormal, with imaging and EEG showing no explanation for his persistent encephalopathy.

The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, which was likely due to a seizure. He has also been experiencing ETOH withdrawal symptoms, which are being managed with medication. He has a history of alcoholic hepatitis and has failed a speech and swallow evaluation.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is experiencing daily episodes of respiratory distress, which are being managed with nebulizers and seroquel.
* Neuro: He has an abnormal neuro exam, with imaging and EEG showing no explanation for his persistent encephalopathy.
* Cardiac: He has a history of cardiac arrest, which was likely due to a seizure.
* Infectious: He has a coag-negative staph bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a history of alcoholic hepatitis and is experiencing ETOH withdrawal symptoms.
* Hematological: He has a history of anemia and is receiving transfusions.
* Renal: He has a history of kidney disease and is receiving dialysis.
* Cardiovascular: He has a history of hypertension and is being managed with medication.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's daily episodes of respiratory distress may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
* Sepsis: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia may lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and ETOH withdrawal symptoms may lead to cardiac arrhythmias if not managed properly.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of alcoholic hepatitis and ETOH withdrawal symptoms may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding if not managed properly.
* Renal failure: The patient's history of kidney disease and ETOH withdrawal symptoms may lead to renal failure if not managed properly.

Based on the patient's current status and potential medical complications, it is recommended that he continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the MICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   #1 Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Previous episodes have
   demonstratred normal ABGs.  Decreased respiratory distress overnight on
   new, increased standing dose of seroquel
   -Cont. trial of Seroquel 200/150/200 w/25mg PRNs (with total of 800mg
   daily MAX) and f/u w/psych recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 20 mg qday (then 10 mg
   qd x 3 days, then 5 mg
   .
   #2 Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #3 Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive
   with unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    No further cultures have come back positive, so [**1-2**] be a contaminate.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 2-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -will keep PICC line in for now as patient has poor access.
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril,
   decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   .
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate
   POs.  Patient is unable to eat by himself as he lacks the motor
   coordination to do so.
   Would like to avoid PEG tube placement as patient would likely not have
   wanted that and given his respiratory status may require intubation for
   PEG placement.
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a recent cardiac arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by PTX, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress, and coag-negative staph bacteremia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient has been improving on prednisone taper, but still experiences daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis, which are managed with nebs and seroquel.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is still abnormal, and the team is considering a possible underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder, as well as superimposed delirium.
* Coag-negative staph bacteremia: The patient has had a positive blood culture, and treatment with vancomycin is ongoing.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on Amlodipine 5mg PO qday, but may become hypertensive during episodes of agitation, which is managed with seroquel.
* Abnormal neuro exam: The patient's neuro exam has begun to improve with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation.
* s/p cardiac arrest: The cause of the cardiac arrest is unknown, and the patient is currently on aspirin and has had a head CT that was unremarkable.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require reintubation if his respiratory distress worsens.
* Sepsis: The patient has a coag-negative staph bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis if not properly treated.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status and abnormal neuro exam may worsen if not properly managed.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure may become hypertensive during episodes of agitation, which can lead to cardiovascular complications.
* Infection: The patient has a PICC line and is at risk for infection, particularly with coag-negative staph bacteremia.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of alcoholic hepatitis and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
* Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's inability to eat by himself and his poor access may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not properly managed.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status, mental status, and blood pressure, and to adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 79.4 kg individual who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute respiratory failure, acute anemia, and altered mental status. Over the past 24 hours, the patient's medications have been adjusted to include increasing the dose of seroquel to 200/150/200 with 25-50mg Q6h, and a max 24h total seroquel dose of 800mg. The patient's PICC line was pulled back, and they have been trying to get out of bed, which may indicate increased activity.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 132/79 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a fluid balance of 4,020 mL with a total out of 3,470 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 5.5-9.1 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 329-391 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range, with the exception of a slightly low calcium level.

The patient's physical examination shows no signs of peripheral vascular disease, skin changes, or neurologic deficits. The patient's respiratory support is minimal, with an oxygen delivery device not in use and an ABG of 38 mmHg.

The patient's medical problems include acute respiratory failure, acute anemia, altered mental status, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute exacerbation. The patient also has a history of anxiety, hypertension, and chronic respiratory failure.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen if not managed appropriately.
2. Anemia: The patient's acute anemia may lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cardiac output if not treated.
3. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels, particularly calcium, may become imbalanced if not monitored and managed appropriately.
4. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may increase the risk of infection.
5. Cardiac arrest: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and acute exacerbation may increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's altered mental status and decreased mobility may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not managed appropriately.
7. Pressure ulcers: The patient's decreased mobility and altered mental status may increase the risk of pressure ulcers.

Based on this information, it is recommended that the patient's medications be continued and adjusted as necessary, that the patient's fluid balance be closely monitored, and that the patient's electrolyte levels be monitored and managed appropriately. Additionally, the patient's respiratory support should be continued and adjusted as necessary, and the patient's nutritional needs should be assessed and managed appropriately.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old man with severe COPD, who had a PEA arrest and has been in the ICU for an extended period. He has been experiencing periodic agitation, which has improved with an increased dose of seroquel. He has a history of coag-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia, but subsequent cultures have been negative. He is currently receiving vancomycin for a total of two weeks.

Vital signs:

* Temperature: 37.1C (98.7F)
* Heart rate: 97 bpm (normal range: 89-119 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 108/70 mmHg (normal range: 79-151/66-103 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute (normal range: 15-33 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* SpO2: 96%

Lab results:

* Hemoglobin: 10.0 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 5.5-9.1 K/uL
* Platelet count: 329-391 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6-0.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 90-135 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: normal range
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.6 g/dL
* LDH: 454 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.6 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's severe COPD puts him at risk for respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and acidosis.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of coag-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is slightly low, which can increase the risk of bleeding.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are slightly abnormal, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
5. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine levels are slightly elevated, which can indicate renal insufficiency.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of stress ulcer prophylaxis and the presence of coag-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's agitation and altered mental status can be a sign of neurological complications, such as sepsis-induced encephalopathy or hypoxic brain injury.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of PEA arrest and the presence of coag-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiogenic shock.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   #1 Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Previous episodes have
   demonstratred normal ABGs.  Decreased respiratory distress overnight on
   new, increased standing dose of seroquel
   -Cont. trial of Seroquel 200/150/200 w/25mg PRNs (with total of 800mg
   daily MAX) and f/u w/psych recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 20 mg qday (then 10 mg
   qd x 3 days, then 5 mg
   .
   #2 Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #3 Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive
   with unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    No further cultures have come back positive, so [**1-2**] be a contaminate.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 2-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -will keep PICC line in for now as patient has poor access.
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril,
   decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   .
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate
   POs.  Patient is unable to eat by himself as he lacks the motor
   coordination to do so.
   Would like to avoid PEG tube placement as patient would likely not have
   wanted that and given his respiratory status may require intubation for
   PEG placement.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a complicated medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a history of seizures. He was transferred back to the ICU from the floor due to recurring episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: He is still experiencing daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which are managed with nebs and seroquel.
* Mental status: He is still experiencing altered mental status, which is likely due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar disorder, or schizoaffective disorder, as well as superimposed delirium.
* Coag-negative staph bacteremia: He has been treated with vancomycin and is expected to complete a 2-week course.
* Hypertension: He has been experiencing hypertension, which is managed with amlodipine and seroquel PRN.
* Abnormal neuro exam: He has an abnormal neuro exam, which is being monitored and treated with seroquel for agitation.
* Cardiac arrest: The cause of his cardiac arrest is unknown, and he is currently being treated with aspirin and beta blockers.
* ETOH abuse: He has a history of EtOH abuse and may have experienced a withdrawal seizure.
* History of alcoholic hepatitis: He has a history of alcoholic hepatitis, which is being monitored.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's recurring episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
* Sepsis: The patient's coag-negative staph bacteremia may lead to sepsis if not treated promptly and effectively.
* Hypertensive crisis: The patient's hypertension may lead to a hypertensive crisis if not managed properly.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's abnormal neuro exam may worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest may lead to cardiac arrhythmias if not managed properly.
* Worsening of COPD: The patient's COPD may worsen if not managed properly.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Seroquel for agitation and hypertension
* Vancomycin for coag-negative staph bacteremia
* Amlodipine for hypertension
* Aspirin for cardiac arrest
* Beta blockers for cardiac arrest
* Folate, thiamine, and MVI for EtOH abuse
* Ground solids and thin liquids for dysphagia
* TF for nutrition
* Heparin for DVT prophylaxis
* PPI for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Bowel regimen for constipation

The patient's disposition is currently being evaluated for rehabilitation, and a guardian has been appointed to make medical decisions on his behalf.

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a prolonged ICU course complicated by recurrent bacteremia, respiratory failure, and altered mental status. He has chronic obstructive lung disease (COPD) and has undergone extubation. The patient's respiratory status has improved with oxygen therapy, and he is being weaned off oxygen as tolerated. His mental status is still tenuous, and he is receiving Seroquel to manage agitation and sedation. The patient's sepsis is being treated with vancomycin, and his anemia is secondary to blood loss.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still compromised, and he may require continued oxygen therapy and bronchodilators to manage his COPD.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is being treated with antibiotics, but he may be at risk for further complications such as organ failure or disseminated infection.
3. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is still tenuous, and he may require continued sedation and medication management to prevent agitation and combative behavior.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is secondary to blood loss, and he may require transfusions to manage his anemia and prevent further complications.
5. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder may require ongoing management to prevent further complications.
6. Wound infection: The patient's wound infection may require ongoing management and treatment to prevent further complications.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is stable, but he may be at risk for further complications such as cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
8. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is normal, but he may be at risk for further complications such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and he may require ongoing nutritional support to manage his anemia and prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.  Now extubated, periodically having anxiety
   leading to tachypnea and fininishing course of Abx for bacteremia,
   screening for rehab.
   .
   #1 Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Previous episodes have
   demonstratred normal ABGs.  Decreased respiratory distress overnight on
   new, increased standing dose of seroquel
   -Cont. Seroquel w/25mg PRNs (with total of 800mg daily MAX) and f/u
   w/psych recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -switch to albuterol and ipratropium MDIs
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 20 mg qday (then 10 mg
   qd x 3 days, then 5 mg
   .
   #2 Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder: Acutely this a.m. most
   likely [**3-15**] large doses of seroquel o/n for agitation o/n which was at
   one point him trying to crawl out of bed.  Chronic likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          Decrease PRN doses of seroquel
   -          Clarify  that PRN seroquel is to be used for anxiety and
   tachypnea not
agitation
 (agitation has many meanings)
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #3 Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  Last + culture was on [**1-2**] and
   had same resistance panel, likely same infection rather than
   contaminant.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2 (most
   recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess for
   aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    No further cultures have come back positive, so [**1-2**]
   represents last positive surveillance culture for now and would treat
   for 14 days past this.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 2-week course after [**1-2**] ([**1-15**])
   -Attempted PICC change but PICC nurse unable to place on opposite side,
   would withdrawl PICC and resite vs. tx w/ linezolid PO if unable to
   resite.
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive/tachycardic w/ anxious/tachypnic episodes, which resolves
   w/seroquel.  On Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg
   of Lisinopril, decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   anxiety/tachypnea
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - No recent neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   .
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
# FEN: passed  a speech and swallow evaluation on [**1-6**] reccomendations were: 1.
 PO diet: ground solids, thin liquids 2. PO meds: crushed in puree 3. 1:1 superv
ision with PO to maintain aspiration precautions and assist with self-feeding.
4. Nutrition f/u re: NGT feedings
5. If there are further concerns for aspiration either clinically
by RN or objectively by CXR, please place videoswallow study
order for further objective assessment of swallow function.
- Nutrition consult for calorie count and if sufficient would pull dopoff
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call
   [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 3793**] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 7-1888 on friday. attorney @[**Hospital1 **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]  .
   .
   #PPX: heparin sc, PPI, bowel regimen.
   .
   #Dispo: Appropriate for rehab. Screening in progress. Transfer to floor
   if not rehab, will need to inform accepting team of frequent episodes
   of tachypnea.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, and a recent cardiac arrest. He was admitted to the ICU with severe respiratory distress, agitation, and coag-negative staph bacteremia. The patient has been extubated and is currently being treated with seroquel for anxiety and agitation, as well as vancomycin for bacteremia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 97.9F, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 119/70 mmHg. His respiratory status has improved, with a SpO2 of 97%. However, he continues to experience daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which are managed with nebs and seroquel.

The patient's mental status has also improved, with decreased agitation and anxiety. However, he still has altered mental status, which is likely due to underlying psychiatric diagnoses, including bipolar disorder and schizoaffective disorder, as well as superimposed delirium.

The patient has a history of coag-negative staph bacteremia, which has been treated with vancomycin. He has had extensive workup, including TTE and MRI of the head and C-spine, which have not shown any evidence of abscess or aneurysm.

The patient's neuro exam has begun to improve, with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation. However, he still has abnormal reflexes, which are being monitored.

The patient's cardiac arrest is still under investigation, with no clear cause identified. He has been started on aspirin and has had a head CT, which was unremarkable.

The patient has a history of EtOH abuse and has been off benzodiazepines for a few weeks. He has been prescribed folate, thiamine, and MVI to manage withdrawal symptoms.

The patient's nutritional status is being monitored, with a speech and swallow evaluation recommending a PO diet with ground solids and thin liquids, as well as supervision during meals to prevent aspiration.

The patient's medical decision-making is being handled by his son, who is pursuing guardianship. The patient's medical team is working to inform the accepting team of his frequent episodes of tachypnea if he is transferred to the floor.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Continued respiratory distress and tachypnea
* Agitation and anxiety
* Bacteremia and sepsis
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Neurological deficits
* Aspiration pneumonia
* Malnutrition and dehydration
* Withdrawal symptoms from EtOH and benzodiazepines
* Complications from the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as COPD and EtOH abuse.
